div.p:
Decandolle finds as the result of his inquiries, that of
all the European species of trees, the yew is that which
attains the greatest age. He assigns to the yew (Taxus
baccata) of Braborne, in the county of Kent, thirty cen-
turies; to the Scotch yew of Fortingal, from twenty-five
to twenty-six; and to those of Crowhurst in Surrey, and
Ripon in Yorkshire respectively fourteen and a-half and
twelve centuries.—(Decandolle, de la Longévité des Arbres, p.
65). Endlicher remarks that the age of another yew-tree
in the churchyard of Gresford, in North Wales, which
measures fifty-two English feet in circumference below the
branches, is estimated at 1400 years, and that of a yew in
Derbyshire at 2096. In Lithuania, lime-trees have been
cut down which were eighty-seven English feet in circum-
ference, and in which 815 annual rings have been counted.
—Humboldt’s Aspects of Nature.
